nodes.name: Slow progress in factored cognition research for AI alignment
nodes.description: Difficulty in developing factored cognition techniques quickly enough to contribute to AI alignment efforts, risking misaligned AI systems.
nodes.node_rationale: Sets the overall motivation; referenced in Abstract and Benefits sections.

nodes.name: Limited scale of factored cognition experiments at Ought
aliases: restricted participant numbers in Ought studies
nodes.description: Current experiments involve few users and weekly/bi-weekly cycles, restricting hypothesis testing and data generation.
nodes.node_rationale: Identified root cause of slow progress; outlined in Benefits section.

nodes.name: Scaling factored cognition experiments tightens feedback loops and increases ML training data
aliases: greater scale yields more data for training
nodes.description: Hypothesis that many simultaneous users would allow root questions to be solved within hours and create sizeable datasets for machine learning.
nodes.node_rationale: Provides reasoning why solving the problem would address the risk; Benefits section.

nodes.name: Creating large-scale online platform for factored cognition similar to Stack Overflow
nodes.description: Design idea to host many concurrent workspace trees, leveraging community Q&A dynamics to support factored cognition workflows.
nodes.node_rationale: Proposed solution approach linking theoretical insight to concrete mechanism; Feasibility section.

nodes.name: Fact Overflow system with workspace trees and user action workflow
nodes.description: Implementation concept: users work on isolated workspaces in a tree, with parameters like contamination factor and action frequency governing quality.
nodes.node_rationale: Details how the design rationale would be operationalised; Feasibility section.

nodes.name: Feasibility modeling of development effort and user requirements based on Stack Overflow data
nodes.description: Rough estimates: 5–15 months development with 2–5 people; 600–36k users needed to finish a question tree in 3 h; 1–22 months to recruit users.
nodes.node_rationale: Provides quantitative backing for plausibility of implementation; Feasibility and Conclusion sections.

nodes.name: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments
nodes.description: Action: allocate a 2–5 person team to develop a Stack-Overflow-like site supporting workspace trees, then recruit 600–36k active users to run 24/7 factored cognition experiments.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Infrastructure creation step preceding any AI model lifecycle phase; see Feasibility section.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only a conceptual proposal with rough estimates, no prototype yet; see Abstract and Conclusion.
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete actionable step derived from the article’s reasoning.

edges.source_node: Slow progress in factored cognition research for AI alignment
edges.target_node: Limited scale of factored cognition experiments at Ought
edges.description: Limited experimental scale restricts data and hypothesis testing, leading to slower overall research progress.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Explicitly stated causal link in Benefits section, though qualitative.
edges.edge_rationale: Benefits section links small-scale experiments to slower feedback loops.

edges.source_node: Limited scale of factored cognition experiments at Ought
edges.target_node: Scaling factored cognition experiments tightens feedback loops and increases ML training data
edges.description: Increasing experiment scale is proposed as a way to alleviate limitations of current small-scale studies.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Direct statement in Benefits; no quantitative proof but clear author claim.
edges.edge_rationale: Benefits section argues larger scale would remedy slow feedback and small data.

edges.source_node: Scaling factored cognition experiments tightens feedback loops and increases ML training data
edges.target_node: Creating large-scale online platform for factored cognition similar to Stack Overflow
edges.description: Need for scale motivates designing a platform that can host many users simultaneously.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Logical inference from discussion; not explicitly mapped.
edges.edge_rationale: Author transitions from benefits of scale to proposing Stack-Overflow-like solution.

edges.source_node: Creating large-scale online platform for factored cognition similar to Stack Overflow
edges.target_node: Fact Overflow system with workspace trees and user action workflow
edges.description: The design rationale would be realised through a specific system architecture employing workspace trees and user workflows.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Implementation details sketched in Feasibility section.
edges.edge_rationale: Feasibility section lays out technical structure following design idea.

edges.source_node: Fact Overflow system with workspace trees and user action workflow
edges.target_node: Feasibility modeling of development effort and user requirements based on Stack Overflow data
edges.description: Comparative modelling using Stack Overflow data offers preliminary validation that building and populating the system is plausible.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Only rough Guesstimate modelling; limited empirical support.
edges.edge_rationale: Feasibility modelling section quantifies development time and user base.

edges.source_node: Feasibility modeling of development effort and user requirements based on Stack Overflow data
edges.target_node: Build and operate Fact Overflow platform for large-scale factored cognition experiments
edges.description: Positive feasibility estimates encourage undertaking the actual development and deployment.
edges.edge_confidence_rationale: Inference: modelling implies project is doable; decision step not explicit.
edges.edge_rationale: Conclusion states it ‘would be useful’ and quantifies required effort, leading to suggested action.

meta.value: The Stack Overflow of Factored Cognition
